responses.rationale: Reports numbers of outbreaks and affected flocks using standard language: 'have already been nine outbreaks', 'affecting seven commercial flocks and two backyard flocks'.
Reports a warning about a potential future worsening situation, not current prices/metrics.
Reports detection of cases and spread to states using standard language: 'were detected', 'having spread to more than 30 states'.
Reports that trading 'has suffered' and imports 'have blocked', describing economic consequences factually without vivid verbs or risk adjectives on metrics.
Reports a farm being 'hit' by disease and lack of disclosure, not prices/metrics.
Reports the predominant strain, not prices/metrics.
Reports a positive test and first detection, not prices/metrics.
Reports numbers of affected farms and states using standard language: 'has been found in 48 commercial farms in 12 states and 32 backyard flocks in 13 states'.
Contains explicit reassuring language: 'remain very rare', 'risk... is still low'.
Contains explicit framing: 'Less reassuring'.
Reports a percentage target using standard language: 'seeking guarantees of 20% global supply'.
Reports the number of manufacturers using standard language: 'include six of the largest seasonal flu manufacturers'.
Reports a timeframe using standard language: 'could take months'.
Reports a timeframe using standard language: 'over four to six months'.
Reports experts' advocacy, not prices/metrics.
Reports results were 'mixed', not prices/metrics.
Reports lack of contracts, not prices/metrics.
Reports a statement about prematurity, not prices/metrics.
Reports numbers of deaths and positive tests using standard language: 'Twenty California condors... have died', 'half... tested positive'.
Reports worry about potential spread, not prices/metrics.
Reports timeframes and rates using standard language: 'taking up to eight years', 'average of one young every other year'.
Reports a 'tremendous impact' and timeframe, not prices/metrics.
Reports a number remaining using standard language: 'only 334 condors remained'.
Reports a likelihood about spread, not prices/metrics.
Reports duration and affected period, not prices/metrics.
Reports detection in a child, not prices/metrics.
Reports a positive test, not prices/metrics.
Reports detection and deaths, not prices/metrics.
Reports strain type and detection history, not prices/metrics.
Reports frequency, not prices/metrics.
Reports prior occurrence, not prices/metrics.
Reports a statement about relief, not prices/metrics.
Reports spread to species and prevalence, not prices/metrics.
Uses 'Only one case' which frames the rarity, not just reporting a number neutrally.
Reports detection at a number of farms using standard language: 'was also detected at two turkey farms', 'was detected at one emu farm'.
This is a question, not reporting prices/metrics.
Reports symptoms developed, not prices/metrics.
Reports lack of testing and reason, not prices/metrics.
Reports frequency and timing of cases coming to light, not prices/metrics.
Reports a confirmed case and its rarity, not prices/metrics.
Reports presence of strains and sporadic infection, not prices/metrics.
Reports dates of hospitalization and diagnosis, not prices/metrics.
Reports lack of details, not prices/metrics.
Reports health condition ('stable', 'ready to be discharged'), which is reassuring language.
Contains explicit framing: 'vivid reminder', 'threat... is persistent'.
Reports the strain is 'not a very common virus', not prices/metrics.
Reports detection, not prices/metrics.
Reports first case and lack of clarity, not prices/metrics.
Reports potential deadliness, not prices/metrics.

Reports detection at various locations and types of flocks using standard language: 'Bird flu has also been detected at commercial turkey farms... a flock... a commercial poultry flock... a backyard flock... and in New York and Maine'.
Reports an outbreak, not prices/metrics.
Reports the number and types of birds on a farm using standard language: 'had 161 birds, including laying hens, ducks, geese, pigeons and peacocks'.
Reports numbers of deaths by specific dates using standard language: '16 laying hens had also died', 'three geese, three peacocks and one duck had died too'.
Reports the situation was described as 'worrying', which is explicit framing.
Reports a death, not prices/metrics.
Reports numbers of deaths and affected states using standard language: 'at least 36 bald eagles have died in 14 states'.
Lists affected species, not prices/metrics.
Reports detection in states, not prices/metrics.
Explicitly states the threat 'remains low', which is reassuring language.
Describes the flu as 'sweeping' and 'taking a toll', which is explicit framing.
Reports a number culled using standard language: 'resulted in the culling of more than 23 million poultry'.
Reports how the virus spreads and its effect ('succumb at a high rate'), not prices/metrics.
Reports prices 'have been rising' using a standard economic verb.
Reports identification in a flock of a specific size and case number using standard language: 'identified bird flu in a commercial flock of 50,000 turkeys', 'the state's second case'.
Reports confirmation and details of a previous case (distance, date, flock size) using standard language: 'confirmed the case', 'case identified March 1 in a backyard flock of 42 ducks and chickens'.
Reports lack of disclosure of a number, not reporting a metric itself.
Reports numbers of farms and flocks using standard language: 'five other commercial farms are within the zone and 37 backyard flocks'.
Describes the discovery as 'especially troubling', which is explicit framing.
Reports numbers killed in a past event using standard language: 'led producers to kill 33 million hens', '9 million birds'.
Reports a potential future outcome ('could become an issue'), not factual reporting of current metrics.
Reports number of states and locations where cases were reported using standard language: 'Cases have been reported in at least 12 states'.
Describes the virus and how it spreads ('spreads easily'), not prices/metrics.
Describes how the virus can spread, not prices/metrics.
Reports the first infection (date, location, type), not prices/metrics.
Reports number of flocks found and number of birds killed using standard language: 'five additional flocks have been found', 'more than 171,000 birds have been killed'.
Reports detection and number of birds destroyed/disposed using standard language: 'was detected', 'resulting in the destruction and disposal of more than 284,000 birds'.
Reports infection and number of birds disposed using standard language: 'was infected, leading to the disposal of 1.2 million birds'.
Reports identification at locations with specific numbers of birds/flocks using standard language: 'have identified the virus... with 240,000 broiler chickens'.
Reports confirmation of first discovery (date, location, type), not prices/metrics.
Reports recent cases, not prices/metrics.
Reports first commercial case (date), not prices/metrics.
Reports prices 'rising rapidly' and costs 'edged higher' using standard verbs and neutral adverb 'rapidly'.
Reports customers 'are paying more' using standard language for price increases.
Reports a price increase using a standard verb: 'raised my prices'.
Reports watching profit/loss and raising prices using standard verbs: 'watch my profit and loss', 'I raise my prices'.
Reports that people 'have to pay more' using standard language for price increases.
Reports prices 'more than doubled' using a standard mathematical description of change.
Reports number killed using standard language: 'More than 24 million chickens... have been killed'.
Reports potential deadliness and spread rate ('spread rapidly'), not prices/metrics.
Reports number of employees laid off and hens destroyed using standard language: 'laid off more than 200 employees', 'forced the destruction of 5.3 million laying hens'.
Uses the vivid verb 'ignited protests'.
Reports an event (protest), not prices/metrics.
Reports first appearance (date, location), not prices/metrics.
Reports spread and numbers of counties/states/provinces using standard language: 'was reported in more than 230 counties in 37 states and at least six Canadian provinces'.
Reports number of species infected using standard language: 'at least 32 species of wild birds have been infected'.
Describes spread using a quote/metaphor ('very clearly on the wings'), not prices/metrics.
Reports numbers gathered and killed using standard language: '40,000 common cranes were gathered killed 8,000 of them'.
Reports opportunities 'has increased', not prices/metrics.
Reports where COVID-19 has been found, not prices/metrics.
Reports a statement about creating opportunities, not prices/metrics.
Reports a statement about pathogens leveraging opportunities, not prices/metrics.
Reports evolution and mutation (timeframe), not prices/metrics.
Reports number of infections and countries affected over a timeframe using standard language: 'has caused 863 human infections in 18 countries since 2003'.
Reports potential infections ('may be infected'), not prices/metrics.
Reports cases emerged at a location, not prices/metrics.
Reports number of birds euthanized using standard language: 'Roughly 800,000 birds... were euthanized'.
Reports spread rate ('spreads easily') and potential deadliness ('can prove deadly'), not prices/metrics.
Describes symptoms ('mild to severe'), not prices/metrics.
Describes potential outcomes ('lead to vomiting, seizures, and death'), not prices/metrics.
Reports number of cases over a timeframe using standard language: 'there have been 27 human cases... reported'.
Reports a potential future number using standard language: 'would bring that figure up to 31'.
Reports skepticism and uses a mild metaphor ('continues to gain ground'), not prices/metrics.
Reports arguments about problems ('haven’t changed dramatically'), not prices/metrics.
Reports numbers of herds and states using standard language: 'more than 155 herds in 13 states have reported infections'.
Reports survey findings about farmer behavior, not prices/metrics.
Reports an update on a cluster of cases, not prices/metrics.
Reports number of cases and their status using standard language: 'The five cases (four are confirmed, one is still considered presumptive) were among people'.

Reports officials noting infected herds, not prices/metrics.
Reports officials saying a genetic sequence indicated relatedness, not prices/metrics.

Reports numbers killed using standard language: '8.1 million birds killed', '5.8 million of those... have come'.

Reports number killed using standard language and neutral quantifier: 'seen only 5.1 million birds killed'.
